block.p: Bush Defends His Tack In Handling North Korea President Bush brushed off signs that Asian nations differ sharply with him about how to handle the nuclear standoff with North Korea, arguing that Japan, South Korea and the European Union joined him in curtailing oil shipments to the country late last year and that the world would work together on the issue.

China's Role in the Koreas A fundamental economic and power shift is taking place in Northeast Asia. Faced with a looming crisis over North Korea's nuclear bomb program, South Korea sent an envoy to its most important economic partner: China. Until a decade ago, South Korea had no diplomatic relations with China, and would have turned to the United States.

Bush Defends His Tack In Handling North Korea President Bush brushed off signs that Asian nations differ sharply with him about how to handle the nuclear standoff with North Korea, arguing that Japan, South Korea and the European Union joined him in curtailing oil shipments to the country late last year and that the world would work together on the issue.

China's Role in the Koreas A fundamental economic and power shift is taking place in Northeast Asia. Faced with a looming crisis over North Korea's nuclear bomb program, South Korea sent an envoy to its most important economic partner: China. Until a decade ago, South Korea had no diplomatic relations with China, and would have turned to the United States.

China to Send Man Into Space Beijing plans to launch a manned capsule into orbit around Earth by the end of the year, speeding up an effort intended to showcase its growing technological abilities and to take advantage of the scientific, military and commercial potential of space.

Boeing Rejects China Charges The Boeing Company rejected State Department accusations that it failed to guard against technology leaks to China, calling security concerns a priority and promising negotiations to resolve the complaints.

Increasing Palestinian Attacks After several new attacks by Palestinians, an official in the office of Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel said, ''The Palestinians appear to have rung in the new year with a campaign of terror.''

No Weapons Found, Iraq Says The Iraqi government said United Nations weapons inspectors had failed to uncover any weapons of mass destruction or evidence of other prohibited programs. The U.N. itself has not disclosed any information about what its inspectors have found.

Kurdish Health Care Worries Throughout the Kurdish region of northern Iraq, doctors and patients are confronting shortages and difficult choices in a health care system they worry might soon collapse. If war comes, doctors say, this strained system will be overwhelmed.

Islamic Militants in Yemen The investigation into two high-profile attacks in Yemen suggests that a larger cell of Islamic militants has been planning to target other foreigners as well as secular-minded politicians, a security official said.

International Effort on Strike Venezuela's embattled president, Hugo Ch√°vez, favors the creation of a group of ''Friends of Venezuela'' to lead an international diplomatic effort to end the monthlong general strike that has crippled oil production and brought normal activity to a halt.

Bush Will Propose Major Medicare Overhaul Administration officials say that President Bush, with the new Senate majority leader as a powerful ally, will propose sweeping long-term changes in Medicare when he urges Congress to provide prescription drug benefits for the elderly this month. The president has told his advisers and Congressional leaders that he wants to promote competition in the program to establish his credentials on an issue likely to figure in the 2004 election.

White House Pushes Secrecy The Bush administration has put a much tighter lid than recent presidents on government proceedings and the public release of information, exhibiting a penchant for secrecy that has been striking to historians, legal experts and lawmakers of both parties.

Bigfoot Outlives Its Creator Bigfoot defenders, including at least two scientists and a clinical psychologist, are undeterred in their beliefs despite the recent death of Ray L. Wallace, the prank-loving Northwesterner who created the modern myth of Bigfoot by stomping a track of oversized footprints in a Northern California logging camp in 1958, using wood-carved feet.

Bill Frist, the newly chosen Senate majority leader, helped paramedics tend to five people who were critically injured in a one-car accident that killed an 11-year-old girl while traveling in Florida along Alligator Alley highway just west of Miami.

Edwards to Run for Presidency Senator John Edwards of North Carolina said that he intended to run for president in 2004, promising that he would ''champion the cause of regular people,'' while harshly condemning President Bush's White House as being ''run for the benefit of insiders.''

New Tax Cuts to Be Announced President Bush said that he would detail his proposal to cut taxes and stimulate the economy on Tuesday, and he brushed aside critics who predicted that his plans would primarily benefit the rich.

Orangutan 'Culture' Is Cited Drawing on decades of research and hundreds of thousands of hours of observations from six sites in the wild, an international team of scientists found evidence that Orangutans, those red-haired knuckle-dragging apes, exhibit what was until very recently considered a uniquely human attribute: culture.

Los Alamos Director Resigns The director of Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico, the nation's pre-eminent nuclear weapons laboratory, has resigned amid investigations into corruption and missing equipment, officials said.

Bloomberg Expands Human Rights Agency Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has doubled the number of investigators and increased the budget of the Human Rights Commission, a city agency that some say was deliberately weakened by former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

Police Kill 4 in 2 Days The police fatally shot two men in unrelated cases yesterday in Harlem and South Brooklyn, a day after officers shot and killed two other men. The police said that three of the shootings appeared justified, and that they were still investigating the fourth.

Study on 9/11 Health Effects New York City and federal health officials are working out the final details of what they say would be the largest study of its kind ever undertaken -- a health registry to follow as many as 200,000 people exposed to ash and dust from the destruction of the World Trade Center.

Seminary to Lease to Columbia Union Theological Seminary plans to lease three of its buildings to its neighbor, Columbia University, for 49 years. It also plans to transfer its million-volume library collection to Columbia.
Ian MacNaughton A British director who helped a group of young comedians shape ''Monty Python's Flying Circus'' into a watershed of absurdist television comedy, he was 76.

Insurers to Pay Morgan Chase J. P. Morgan Chase reached a settlement with insurance companies and will collect about $580 million of the $1 billion it had sought to cover losses resulting from complex transactions with Enron. The bank will take a $400 million charge.

Report Spurs Stock Surge An unexpectedly strong report on manufacturing powered the largest first-day-of-the-year gain in stock prices since 1988. All three major market averages rose by more than 3 percent on a relatively light volume of 1.23 billion shares.

Label Dispute Delays Drug The company hoping to sell a generic version of Rebetol, a Hepatitis C drug whose patent expired in June, says federal approval is being held up by a technicality -- a dispute about the drug's label.

GE to Finance US Airways GE Capital has agreed to provide additional financing for US Airways in exchange for a small equity stake. The companies also renegotiated loan repayment terms, aircraft lease rates and terms of engine servicing.
Editorials: A bad bet; partners in flight; Germany takes center stage; Christmas trees pine to be mulched.
